content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would choose a strategy that maximizes the average payoff while minimizing the risk of zero payout. In this game, if both players consistently pick the same option (either R or B), they will earn a steady income over time.

However, since the optimal strategy is not clear from the start due to the presence of an anonymous player, I would adopt a mixed strategy. A mixed strategy involves making random choices between two options (R and B) in a way that leans towards the more profitable outcome when both players choose the same option. In this case, I would lean slightly towards R because it provides a higher average payoff per round (45$) compared to B (12$).

For the 75 rounds of the game, I would maintain a slight bias towards R while ensuring randomness in my choices to avoid predictability. My choice for this particular round is:

{R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent and I both picked R in the previous round, I earned a payoff of 45$. Given the same circumstances, I would stick to the strategy of maintaining a slight bias towards R for the next round as well:
